q1.description:
The necessary capabilities for any such "machine" are these:
- Read
- Write
- Compute
q1.question: Please select all the capabilities of a States Machine

q15.description: A Turing machine is defined as follows. It has a one-dimensional tape, divided into squares. This tape extends infinitely to the left and to the right.
q15.question: How many squares does the tape on the left have?

q16.description:
A Turing machine is defined as follows. It has a one-dimensional tape, divided into squares. This tape extends infinitely to the left and to the right.
Each square can store one character.
q16.question: How many squares are requiered to store the string $aaaa$ on the tape on the left?

q20.description:
A Turing machine is defined as follows. It has a one-dimensional tape, divided into squares. This tape extends infinitely to the left and to the right.
Each square can store one character.
q20.question: The remaining squares will be marked blank by using the # symbol

q22.description:
A Turing machine is defined as follows. It has a one-dimensional tape, divided into squares. This tape extends infinitely to the left and to the right.
Each square can store one character.
The machine has a single I/O head that at any instant in time is "on" one of the squares.
The control unit of the machine is defined by a set of abstract $states$.
q22.question: Suppose the TM on the left, how many states the TM have?

q23.description:
A Turing machine is defined as follows. It has a one-dimensional tape, divided into squares. This tape extends infinitely to the left and to the right.
Each square can store one character.
The machine has a single I/O head that at any instant in time is "on" one of the squares.
The control unit of the machine is defined by a set of abstract $states$.
At any given instant, the machine is said to be "in" one of the states, and has a set of actions that can be performed when in that state.
q23.question: In which state the machie is now?

q24.description:
It is worth to note that once the TM starts, the tape head will start at the leftmost non-blank tape cell.
From the current state, the machine will read the symbol on the current square
q24.question: The machine head will start at index 1 and will read the current cell letter: $a$

q25.description:
From the current state, the machine will read the symbol on the current square, and will then do the following (depending on the value of the symbol that it sees):
1. Overwrite that symbol with a new symbol,
2. Move the tape head either left (L), right (R), or stay (S)
q25.question: In TM tape, the # symbole means empty cell, or erase the current cell. Based on the current trasition, what will be the new value for the current tape cell?

q26.description:
From the current state, the machine will read the symbol on the current square, and will then do the following (depending on the value of the symbol that it sees):
1. Overwrite that symbol with a new symbol,
2. Move the tape head either left (L), right (R), or stay (S)
q26.question: Based on the current trasition, what will be the head movement direction?
q26.answer: R: go to the cell on the right
choices: R: go to the cell on the right
L: go to the cell on the left
S: stay on the current cell

q27.description:
From the current state, the machine will read the symbol on the current square, and will then do the following (depending on the value of the symbol that it sees):
1. Overwrite that symbol with a new symbol,
2. Move the tape head either left (L), right (R), or stay (S)
q27.question: Based on the current trasition, what will happen to the tape and the head?
q27.answer: erase the current letter and go to the cell on the right
choices: erase the current letter and go to the cell on the right
leave the current letter and go to the cell on the right
erase the current letter and go to the cell on the left
leave the current letter and go to the cell on the left
erase the current letter and stay at the current cell
leave the current letter and stay at the current cell

q33.answer: leave the current letter and stay at the current cell

q34.description: A Turing machine is $\textbf{formally defined}$ as $(Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, q_0, F, \delta)$
q34.question: What is $Q$?

q35.description: A Turing machine is $\textbf{formally defined}$ as $(Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, q_0, F, \delta)$.

q37.description: A Turing machine is $\textbf{formally defined}$ as $(Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, q_0, F, \delta)$.

q38.description: A Turing machine is $\textbf{formally defined}$ as $(Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, q_0, F, \delta)$.
q38.question: $\delta$ is a partial function from $Q \times \Gamma$ to $Q \times \Gamma \times \{L, R, S\})$ means that the $\delta$ function takes the current state and the current tape letter as parameters

q39.description: A Turing machine is $\textbf{formally defined}$ as $(Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, q_0, F, \delta)$.
q39.question: $\delta$ is a partial function from $Q \times \Gamma$ to $Q \times \Gamma \times \{L, R, S\})$ means that the result of the $\delta$ function is
answer: the new tape letter that will be written on the current tape
Move the head after writing the letter
choices: the new tape letter that will be written on the current tape
Move the head after writing the letter
Move the head before writing the letter

q50.description:
Here is an example of a machine that is slightly more complicated. This Turing machine accepts the language $L(a^*b^*c^*)$

$M = (Q, Σ, Γ, s, F, δ)$
• $Q = \{q_0, q_1, q_2, q_3\}$,
• $Σ = \{a, b, c\}$,
• $Γ = Σ ∪ \{\#\} $,
• $s = q_0$,
• $F = q_2$,
• $δ = $
         ---------------------------------
          $q$     $Γ$     $(q, Γ, \{L, R, S\})$
         ---------------------------------
          $q_0$   $a$      $(q_0, a, R)$
          $q_0$   $b$      $(q_1, b, R)$
          $q_0$   $c$      $(q_2, c, R)$
          $q_0$   $\#$     $(q_3, \#, S)$
          $q_1$   $b$      $(q_1, b, R)$
          $q_1$   $c$      $(q_2, c, R)$
          $q_1$   $\#$     $(q_3, \#, S)$
          $q_2$   $c$      $(q_2, c, R)$
          $q_2$   $\#$     $(q_3, \#, S)$
q50.question: What is the type of this language?

q51.description:
Here is an example of a machine that is slightly more complicated. This Turing machine accepts the language $L(a^*b^*c^*)$

$M = (Q, Σ, Γ, s, F, δ)$
• $Q = \{q_0, q_1, q_2, q_3\}$,
• $Σ = \{a, b, c\}$,
• $Γ = Σ ∪ \{\#\} $,
• $s = q_0$,
• $F = q_2$,
• $δ = $
         ---------------------------------
          $q$     $Γ$     $(q, Γ, \{L, R, S\})$
         ---------------------------------
          $q_0$   $a$      $(q_0, a, R)$
          $q_0$   $b$      $(q_1, b, R)$
          $q_0$   $c$      $(q_2, c, R)$
          $q_0$   $\#$     $(q_3, \#, S)$
          $q_1$   $b$      $(q_1, b, R)$
          $q_1$   $c$      $(q_2, c, R)$
          $q_1$   $\#$     $(q_3, \#, S)$
          $q_2$   $c$      $(q_2, c, R)$
          $q_2$   $\#$     $(q_3, \#, S)$
q51.question: Does the machine change the tape content while processing language strings?

q61.description:
Let us see how this machine will accept/reject strings
What about the string $abac$?
q61.question: What will happen?
q61.answer: The machine will halt by following an undefined transition. So the string is rejected
